name: o-diethylbenzene
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: 1,1-diethylbenzene has a melting point that can be predicted by considering its structural components. The basic unit for comparison is ethylbenzene, which has a melting point of -106.0 degrees Celsius. The introduction of two additional phenyl groups linked in a linear fashion raises the melting point due to the enhancement of the crystalline structure and the increase in molecular weight. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight.
